jacques-n commented on issue #2902: ARROW-3698: [Gandiva] Segmentation fault when using a large table in Gandiva
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2902#issuecomment-435723847
 
 
   I believe Gandiva was designed such that a single batch/table of records can't be more 2^32-1. This is consistent with the java definition of a table and the original Arrow spec (before it was expanded). You should probably be breaking your table into that size or smaller. Beyond that size, you're talking about a contiguous allocation of greater than 8gb or 16gb+ pre column. @pravindra @praveenbingo , thoughts?

   @jacques-n - our initial implementation assumed 2^32-1 limit on the array. but @wesm pointed out that the this had changed, and he/praveen fixed a bunch of related issues at the time of the merge. We probably missed the selection-vector and bitmap code.
   
   I think we should keep gandiva-cpp in-sync with arrow-cpp, so it should support the large record batches. @suquark we should add a test for the large batch.

suquark commented on issue #2902: ARROW-3698: [Gandiva] Segmentation fault when using a large table in Gandiva
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2902#issuecomment-436105618
 
 
   @pravindra  I found some code paths finally reach `ArrowBuf` which extends `io.netty.buffer.AbstractByteBuf` who is using `int` instead of `long`. This will not affect cpp or other languages though, but it will limit Java to 2GB memory when dealing with arrow objects with a buffer.
   
   What should I do here? What I think is to check the size when using `ArrowBuf` and convert long to int.

pravindra commented on issue #2902: ARROW-3698: [Gandiva] Segmentation fault when using a large table in Gandiva
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2902#issuecomment-436223300
 
 
   
   > What should I do here? What I think is to check the size when using `ArrowBuf` and convert long to int.
   
   @suquark since we know that the java doesn't support > "int" size for batch, my suggestion is to 
   
   - leave the java signatures as int (same as before)
   
   - leave the jni signatures also as int. cast to int64_t before making the cpp call
   
   This way, gandiva-cpp will be consistent with arrow-cpp, gandiva-java will be consistent with arrow-java and gandiva-jni will be doing the bridging between the two.

{code}
>>> import pyarrow as pa
Registry has 519 pre-compiled functions
>>> import pandas as pd
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import pyarrow.gandiva as gandiva
>>> import timeit
>>>
>>> from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
>>> for scale in range(25, 26):
... frame_data = 1.0 * np.random.randint(0, 100, size=(2**scale, 2))
... df = pd.DataFrame(frame_data).add_prefix("col")
... table = pa.Table.from_pandas(df)
...
>>>
>>> def float64_add(table):
... builder = gandiva.TreeExprBuilder()
... node_a = builder.make_field(table.schema.field_by_name("col0"))
... node_b = builder.make_field(table.schema.field_by_name("col1"))
... sum = builder.make_function(b"add", [node_a, node_b], pa.float64())
... field_result = pa.field("c", pa.float64())
... expr = builder.make_expression(sum, field_result)
... projector = gandiva.make_projector(table.schema, [expr], pa.default_memory_pool())
... return projector
...
>>> projector = float64_add(table)
>>> projector.evaluate(table.to_batches()[0])
[1] 36393 segmentation fault python{code}
It is because there is an integer overflow in Gandiva:
[https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/1a6545aa51f5f41f0233ee0a11ef87d21127c5ed/cpp/src/gandiva/projector.cc#L141]

It should be `int64_t` instead of `int`.
